newsitem.title: CZECH REPUBLIC: CZECH RULING COALITION AGREES TO DEREGULATE RENTS.
newsitem.headline: CZECH RULING COALITION AGREES TO DEREGULATE RENTS.

text.p: The Czech ruling coalition agreed on Thursday to fully deregulate almost all rent-controls on housing by 2000, Prime Minister Vaclav Klaus told a news conference.
Only a small segment for socially disadvantaged residents would be kept under rent controls after 2000, he said.
"We would want to finalise the (housing) deregulation in the year 2000," Klaus said. "That is a quite ambitious aim."
He said that an across the board rise for 1997 in controlled rents, ahead of full deregulation, would be discussed in a cabinet session on Friday.
In 1998, rents would be fully deregulated in communities with less than 10,000 inhabitants.
The deregulation steps would be included in a package of social assistance measures, including state promotion of new housing construction, Klaus said.
He did not elaborate on the details of the programme.
The decision came during a meeting of leaders of the three parties which make up the centre-right coalition government.
The parties agreed to make a joint decision on housing and energy deregulation policy in the coalition agreement which formed the government following 1996 general elections.
Concrete steps of the plan still require formal approval by the government.
The coalition leaders continued their meeting late on Thursday to discuss electricity, heating, and gas price deregualtion.
